messages.text: hi I have some type-unstable code which gets flagged by `@code_warntype` . The issue seems to be a function `f(params, opts::MyOptions=MyOptions(); args...)`  and more specifically the way I supply the standard options for my package. I have seen in other Julia packages that this seems to be standard practice, so I am wondering whether there is a way to get this type-stable and if so how to do it.

messages.text:
if I have 2 vectors of different types, with discrete (and not uniform) values, is there an easy way to create a matrix which counts the combinations of the elements per index?
I.e. say A holds a vector of characters and B holds a vector of integers, then M shall be the matrix where each row corresponds to a unique value of A (char) and each column corresponds to a unique value of B (integer) and the entry at the corresponding row and column shall hold the number of indices where the corresponding elements show up together.

I.e. say A holds a vector of characters and B holds a vector of integers, then M shall be the matrix where each row corresponds to a unique value of A (char) and each column corresponds to a unique value of B (integer) and the entry at the corresponding row and column shall hold the number of indices where the corresponding elements show up together.

messages.text:
for A=['a', 'a', 'c', 'c'] and B=[1, 3, 1, 50] this would mean M being
```1 1 0
1 0 1```
since rows are for 'a' and 'c' and columns are for 1, 3 and 50

messages.text:
Hi, I had a question about the package manager.

I am developing a personal package `X`. This package depends on a package available in the julia registry `R`.

So I do
`]activate X`
`add R`

This installs a very old version of `R` (in fact a version that breaks).

Alternatively, I try (assuming I want v0.3 of `R`)

```]activate X
add R@0.3```

messages.text:
Hi! I'm having issues with JuMP, when trying to solve a problem with multiple nonlinear constraints...
So for example if I have a multivariable problem with nonlinear constraint function `constraints()` which returns 2 equality constraints, is it possible to do something like
```model = Model(with_optimizer(Ipopt.Optimizer, print_level=2))
@variable(model, xvar[1:2])

register(model, :constraint, 2, constraints, jac_constraints)
@NLexpression(model, cs[1:2], constraints(xvar...))
for ii = 1:2
    @NLconstraint(model, cs[ii]==0)
end```
Currently, when doing something like the above, I get an error as follows:
`ERROR: LoadError: TypeError: in typeassert, expected Float64, got a value of type Array{Float64,1}`

messages.text: I’m using VS Code to edit my project, and I lost the possibility to CTRL + click (or F12) to go to definition of for instance a function or struct (applies to functions or structs defined in my own project). I found that if I use the include statement to load a module into scope then “go to definition” work fine, but if I use import or using statements it won’t work. Is there a way to make this work with import and using statements?

elements.text: I’m using VS Code to edit my project, and I lost the possibility to CTRL + click (or F12) to go to definition of for instance a function or struct (applies to functions or structs defined in my own project). I found that if I use the include statement to load a module into scope then “go to definition” work fine, but if I use import or using statements it won’t work. Is there a way to make this work with import and using statements?

messages.text: Hi :slightly_smiling_face: How do I use `Interpolations.jl` for a coordinate-indexed 2D grid where each grid point has multiple values? I can give it node positions and an array with size `(m, n)` , which then interpolates a single quantity on that grid. I'd like to interpolate 3 quantities on that grid, but neither a `(m, n, 3)` array nor a 3-vector of `(m, n)` arrays seem to work with any of the constructors (throws since methods are missing).

messages.text:
I have a question in embedded julia and arrays. The docs says that one can share array data without copying. There are two situations. Essentially, arrays' memory can be under the control of Julia's GC or under the C side.
Assume I have it under C side:
```double *existingArray = (double*)malloc(sizeof(double)*10);
jl_array_t *x = jl_ptr_to_array_1d(array_type, existingArray, 10, 0);```
Now how can I be notified that julia is done with all references to that `x` ? I cannot call `free` until that's the case. There doesn't seem to be a way to attach a finalizer to `x`. Or is there?

messages.text: Is there a good guide anywhere for how exactly the `where T`-type syntax works (I’m particularly interested at the moment in the context of defining functions on parametric types, including abstract ones) and when/how I need to use it? I feel like my mental model for this is weak and I tend to just try things combinatorially until the code seems to be doing what I want. :laughing: I’ve read through the “Types” section of the manual but haven’t managed to find it there. I found a couple examples of its use in the “Methods” (e.g. <https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/methods/#Parametrically-constrained-Varargs-methods|here>) section but also no explanation of how it actually works.

Suppose I have a `Tuple` of n-dimensional arrays of same size stored in `arrays`. Does this syntax fuse operations in one loop?:
```reduce((x,y) -> x .* y, arrays)```

I'm trying to write a wrapper for the D3.js library in Julia. I saw very old packages that tried to do the same. But I'm having a hard time understanding how they were approaching the problem. Does anyone has any tips on how I could start such project? I mean, tutorials or other resources on writings wrappers as such. I've tried reading the code in some other packages that do similar things, but it's quite tough to understand.
Any tips will be welcomed! I'm quite lost even on how I should approach it.

messages.text:
I’m curious if anyone is aware or uses a particular pattern for “module-specific” dispatching; i.e. dispatching to a method overloaded by a particular module. The pattern I’m thinking about is something like:
```module InterfacePkg

function foo end

# generic fallback definition; pass `nothing` for module
foo(::Type{T}) where {T} = foo(nothing, T)

# fallback if module hasn't overloaded
foo(mod, ::Type{T}) where {T} = nothing

end # InterfacePkg

module ImplPkg

using InterfacePkg

struct ImplStruct end

InterfacePkg.foo(::???, ::Type{ImplStruct}) = "ImplStruct"

end # ImplPkg```
My question is what to use for the `mod` and `???` arguments. `Val`? Some `abstract type` w/ overloading modules defining their own subtype? There isn’t a more obvious/builtin way to “dispatch” on modules, is there?

elements.text: I’m curious if anyone is aware or uses a particular pattern for “module-specific” dispatching; i.e. dispatching to a method overloaded by a particular module. The pattern I’m thinking about is something like:

module InterfacePkg

function foo end

# generic fallback definition; pass `nothing` for module
foo(::Type{T}) where {T} = foo(nothing, T)

# fallback if module hasn't overloaded
foo(mod, ::Type{T}) where {T} = nothing

end # InterfacePkg

module ImplPkg

using InterfacePkg

struct ImplStruct end

InterfacePkg.foo(::???, ::Type{ImplStruct}) = "ImplStruct"

end # ImplPkg
My question is what to use for the
w/ overloading modules defining their own subtype? There isn’t a more obvious/builtin way to “dispatch” on modules, is there?

messages.text:
Hi guys, I have some type instability that I do not understand..
```mutable struct LinearMap{T}
  m::Int
  n::Int
  mul!::Function
  mulc!::Function
  getidx::Function
  _tmp::Union{Array{T}, Nothing}
end

Base.getindex(A::LinearMap, ::Colon, ::Colon) = A.getidx(1:A.m, 1:A.n)
Base.getindex(A::LinearMap, rows, ::Colon) = A.getidx(rows, 1:A.n)
Base.getindex(A::LinearMap, ::Colon, cols) = A.getidx(1:A.m, cols)
Base.getindex(A::LinearMap, rows, cols) = A.getidx(rows, cols)

m = 1000; n = 1000
Id(i,j) = Matrix{Float64}(i.*ones(length(j))' .== ones(length(i)).*j')
IdOp = LinearMap{Float64}(n, n, (y,_,x) -> x, (y,_,x) -> x, (i,j) -> Id(i,j), nothing)

@code_warntype getindex(IdOp, 1:10, 1:10)
@code_warntype IdOp.getidx(1:10, 1:10)```
the second `@code_warntype`  does not return an instability so it seems to be some issue with the forwarding. Any ideas?

elements.text: Hi guys, I have some type instability that I do not understand..

mutable struct LinearMap{T}
  m::Int
  n::Int
  mul!::Function
  mulc!::Function
  getidx::Function
  _tmp::Union{Array{T}, Nothing}
end

Base.getindex(A::LinearMap, ::Colon, ::Colon) = A.getidx(1:A.m, 1:A.n)
Base.getindex(A::LinearMap, rows, ::Colon) = A.getidx(rows, 1:A.n)
Base.getindex(A::LinearMap, ::Colon, cols) = A.getidx(1:A.m, cols)
Base.getindex(A::LinearMap, rows, cols) = A.getidx(rows, cols)

m = 1000; n = 1000
Id(i,j) = Matrix{Float64}(i.*ones(length(j))' .== ones(length(i)).*j')
IdOp = LinearMap{Float64}(n, n, (y,_,x) -> x, (y,_,x) -> x, (i,j) -> Id(i,j), nothing)

@code_warntype getindex(IdOp, 1:10, 1:10)
@code_warntype IdOp.getidx(1:10, 1:10)
does not return an instability so it seems to be some issue with the forwarding. Any ideas?

messages.text:
Hi there - very basic Julia modules question, so apologies to bother you with it here - but googling this yields a ton of old threads on stack exchange with either deprecated information or dead links to parts of the Julia docs that have apparently been removed/deleted. So I'm posting it here in the hopes that someone can help me out.

Let's suppose I have some file in this kind of directory structure that I'd like to run:
```super_folder/sub_folder/subsub_folder/subsubsub_folder/my_file.jl```
and I'd like to use functions from a custom module within that file, where the `.jl` file for the module itself is stored in a higher up directory, relative to my original `my_file.jl`
for instance,
```super_folder/ModuleStuff.jl```
How do I specify the `include()` statement for the module, at the top of `my_file.jl`

Before, when `my_file.jl` wasn't too "deep", relative to `ModuleStuff.jl` 's location, I was using statements like
```include("../ModuleStuff.jl")```
to account for `my_file.jl`  being a few folders deeper in the file hierarchy than `ModuleStuff` , but unfortunately the `.` notation only works in these include statements for at maximum *two* levels of hierarchy. With the current structure I laid out above^, you'd have to use four dots (`include("..../ModuleStuff.jl")`) to get into the folder with `ModuleStuff.jl` and that doesn't work apparently.

I assume the answer has something to do with pushing `ModuleStuff.jl` to my `LOAD_PATH` variable, but unfortunately I can't find any recent information on the best way to do that, and whether that's even the best solution for my problem. There are a ton of answers online that suggest to statements like
```push!( LOAD_PATH, "/path_to_module" )```
but it's unclear to me _where_ exactly to execute that code. Is that supposed to be at the top of `my_file.jl`? Or do I just have to run it once in some instance of the REPL and my LOAD_PATH variable will now permanently have the paths to my custom modules in it?

messages.text:
Hi Conor
I assume you are in an project environment and have a default file structure like this:
Project.jl
   |__ src-folder
   |__ Project.jl file
All your source files should live in the src folder. If this is the case you can reach every file sitting in the src folder with the following:
include(“your file.jl”)
If you have a subfolder structure in the src-folder then the following should work:
include(“common/your_file.jl)
The subfolder common sits in the src-folder.

HTH
Frank

elements.text:

   |__ Project.jl file
All your source files should live in the src folder. If this is the case you can reach every file sitting in the src folder with the following:
include(“your file.jl”)
If you have a subfolder structure in the src-folder then the following should work:
include(“common/your_file.jl)
The subfolder common sits in the src-folder.

HTH
Frank
